pros: Overall Lamar has been a great place to work. I've been with Lamar Advertising for eight years now and it's been a wonderful experience. The company invests in their people with a lot of internal training which leads to growth opportunities. The benefits are great. I consider myself fortunate to be a part of Lamar Advertising, and as long as the company is willing to have me, I have no intentions of leaving.
cons: Personally I have not experience any significant downsides to working at Lamar. Like any position, there are both pros and cons specific to the role. In my case, commissions can cause variable monthly pay. But of course its expected in my line of work. Frequent daily travel, sometimes involving hours of windshield time can be taxing. To avoid burnout, it is crucial to plan and be efficient in the field. Nevertheless, the advantage is that you get to be on the move and encounter new surroundings multiple times a week, which helps maintain a sense of freshness and variety.

I was constantly pitted against other employees, being told that their jobs were in jeopardy and I had only to prove myself to get a chance for promotion, then sworn to secrecy while they had those same employees train me for their own jobs. I was promised salary increases based on performance, and when goals were met, excuses were made. The GM even offered me a personal loan when I made the case for why I deserved a promised raise. The good old boys thing got REALLY old. Our office was full of cute, young women who were also extremely capable, but were treated like window dressing, being sent out drinking with the bigwigs from corporate when they came visiting. They called it a big family, but only childless young women were hired for administrative positions and those that did get pregnant never lasted more than a year or two, tops. The pay was a joke compared to the workload/responsibility and you only ever got a cost of living raise no matter how hard you worked, or didn't...unless you got promoted, and then you better shoot for the stars because once your title changes, your new salary is fixed no matter how competent you prove yourself to be.

pros: Good company. Greensboro Branch works 4 10hr days. They do seem to value family time but allow for overtime if you want it. Anthony is a heck of an OPS manager! He doesn't sit in office doing paperwork all the time like other OPS managers do. He goes out every day and busts his butt with the employees he supervises. Very respectable. At the same time he's sociable, understanding, but expects work. Couldn't have asked for any better. Crew I worked with was great group of guys as well...helpful, sociable, and good workers. Days when you're installing poster ads or vinyls (billboard ads), you have that independence. It's just you, your truck, and the ads you are scheduled to install that day. Great exercise since you're climbing a lot of structures. Room for advancement.
cons: Collectively these factors lead me to finally move on from the company Tired of working in 90° heat while having to wear hard hat, long pants, and gloves while climbing and/or performing construction on structures. Worked a lot throughout my life outside in the elements and I was finally just done with it. They stress on safety being first and have measures in place to help prevent injuries/death but after few months on the job I realized there were still plenty of dangerous aspects that were obviously never going to be addressed because the only way to eliminate them is to make drastic changes that will cost them astronomically up front as well as cut into their profits for the foreseeable future. Got to the point I was unwilling to continue risking my safety. Work there and you'll see. And finally, I'm in shape. I value my overall longevity and strive to be able to get around well and be very active at least up into my 70's. I've had couple car accidents and the ligament damage and spinal compression fracture I suffered in those accidents many years ago didn't stop me. I recovered well and kept true to my workout regimen. However, after several months of performing the work this job requires, I realized that it was beginning to expose those injuries. I wanted to get out before the job started having serious effects on my body. You don't always just install ads. It involves actual construction work such as tearing down or repairing structures, as well as building new ones. All in all, long as you're a good worker and willing to endure the stress on your body, it has its perks. Though there are chances for additional certifications to increase your salary, coming in as an entry level installer you're going to be disappointed in the pay. It's not nearly enough for the risks involved. Just didn't feel this job was worth wasting any more time on.

title: Can't see the forest through the trees
pros: Discounted stock plan, management gives you freedom to sell to whomever you want, every day is different.
cons: Base salary is near poverty level, so if you have an off month (which will happen), good luck eating and paying your bills that month. Car and phone allowance is archaic. Budgets are rarely delivered on time and are only released a quarter at a time. Comp plans are atrocious (2% of sales at 100% of plan, even less in other markets) and are constantly changing with plenty of "ah ha!" ways to nip at your wallet.. The management in your office does not want you making more money than what they make. Company constantly cuts off nose to spite the face. IE: Economy got worse, they cut out the training for new employees. Layoffs trimmed work force so that reps have to deal with every aspect of their accounts which takes away from their ability to do what they were hired for...selling!!! Role is in outside sales and so much of your time is spent in the office dealing with a minutia of small projects. General Managers are paid on cash flow, and they are extremely cheap, as is the corporate office. Constant do as I say not as I do mindset; the corporate execs fly around on the company bird while their local offices can't get buy a TV to do presentations on or even take a long standing client to lunch. Operations crew has union mindset so can do whatever they want and there's nothing management can do about it. No room for growth if you're a sales rep.

title: SALES--Environment varies from Plant to Plant....Be very careful in Shreveport, LA.
pros: Team environment is strong, so must be a team player. Pay can be very good, but you have to learn how to play the game and be patient. It may take a couple/ few years to really get how things work, but it can be rewarding none the less while you're battling through the attrition. Training and freedom to sell is provided, then you better prove you can produce. However, you also have enough freedom to hang yourself. If you're not self-motivated then don't waste your time or the company's time. Overall, good family environment on the local level.
cons: As mentioned, the office environment varies from for each Lamar plant. Your plant GM will control all, so be sure you are comfortable working closely with that person. During interview process, ask many questions about the things that are important to you. Many promises will be made. Consider them carefully and ask specific detail-oriented questions. You will experience favoritism, but if you produce, that can be to your benefit. Lastly, Lamar will protect their General Managers so be prepared for that. Poor behavior, bad business (unethical) practices and a bully mentality are just a few of the Cons experienced in my plant. If you can take it, then you can make it. However, it is unfortunate the impact that it has on the community. Regional and HR will let this behavior continue, so be careful.

title: Good company with bad management.
pros: It's a big corporation with a small business feel. Offices all over the US so you can work virtually anywhere. Decent pay and benefits.
cons: Micromanaged to death. Managers are afraid to make decisions without higher approval. A lot of threatening to be fired if a mistake is made. A Feel of you have to watch your own back because the next person will " throw you under the bus ".

title: Their Training and management is trash
pros: The money was good enough.
cons: The management was terrible. They wont give you a chance, they expect you to learn everything in 2 weeks with very minimal and inadequate training. they basically had me watching tons of youtube videos and the sales manger micromanaging my every move. it had me feeling I wasn't enough but soon realized they wanted me to just give them every waking moment.

title: Unfortunate that a company with such potential for success is an internal failure
pros: If given the territory promised upon hire as well as the pay scale there is great potential for amazing income. Make sure that you get this signed off on by management prior to employment acceptance. If you are fortunate enough to be in an area with a dedicated GM you will thrive. Otherwise , you may get GM who has a beverage in their hand by 5:00.
cons: Taking customers away that you worked very hard for and giving to the house account pending if the house account is behind on the monthly budget. Management taking budget number from an AE to make the house account budget for the month. Holding onto credits and making the AE look bad. Pending on the location you may have a GM who does not work 8 hours a day but expects the AE to work 10-12 hours+ a day. Bad management will cause pure chaos at Lamar as they do not know how to create a successful environment and will run an AE into the ground with useless tasks. They will make you drive hours out of your way for a 30-minute meeting that they are not prepared for, and it will take you hours to get back to your territory and then additional hours home to ensure your days are wasted each week. This WILL ABSOLUTELY ensure failure for the AE. This will fall on the AE and not management as they will be sure to place blame to upper management on the AE. If you are in an area that has good management do not leave, you are quite fortunate!!

title: Good Company, Bad experience **Location has been changed, as I don't want my identity revealed in my small town**
pros: Part Salary/Part Comission, Great benefits, comission structure works well if you have encouraging management. Loved the company, wish I could have been trained under someone different, I think I would probably still be there if I had been.
cons: Management drove me away, there was yelling and disrespect in my local office from the management.

title: Mostly Great
pros: Relaxed work environment, generally positive people
cons: My manager was very micromanaging and never seemed to gain any trust that his employees would do their jobs if they were working remotely. Overheard several racist, homophobic, and transphobic conversations that made me feel very uncomfortable.

title: Good Old Boys Club
pros: Corporate has a great environment. Pay is above average for market.
cons: Women are set up for failure. Men are respected more so. Definitely selling in a “man’s world” and have been told so. Management poorly trained. Actually, not trained at all. Toxic office environment. Females reps have been the lowest paid for years in plant, not given equal opportunities.

title: Sales Manager
pros: Lots of ability to affect change with the autonomy in the different plants. Lots of collaboration and growth available only if you're willing to relocate though.
cons: Lamar's plant level autonomy creates a situation in which there is no consistent set of rules. This creates chaos so employees are constantly disgruntled. Their structure really needs improvement. TRAINING is lacking in every way!

title: Great Company, little pay
pros: The people are amazing. I loved everyone I worked with and the company culture is like no other. You will never find a more fun and relaxed work enviornment. Work-life balance is awesome unless you are a sales rep. Great benefits.
cons: The pay is very low and not competitive at all. No defined job hierarcy for current employees to strive for. Management could be better but again the people are what make this job.

title: Installer
pros: Good Benefits, some good people to work with most of the time
cons: Doesn't pay very well. Everyone gets the same raise even if you sit on your butt or work you tail off. No incentive to go above and beyond or take on more responsibility.

title: Title
pros: Nice people. Fun and friendly environment. Quite a bit of freedom over design ideas and concepts. Pretty good stock options available after 1 year.
cons: Unless you are in sales there is no way to effectively increase your pay or to advance in the company. You will be asked to take on more and more responsibility and often even a second job title and responsibilities with very little monetary compensation for the extra work load and stress.

title: Good company
pros: Flexibility Good commission Corporate is there to support sales force
cons: This is a draw+commission micromanagement, which is really annoying when you are on a draw. Other media is just way more viable, like digital advertising. Customers want metrics and data for results driven campaigns and outdoor advertising can’t do that.

title: Bill Poster
pros: Always something different and very physical and hands on work to keep you in shape. Very exhilarating to work at elevated heights on a daily basis. And possibility for pay advancement based on how you want to pursue it. Off at 2:30 most everyday.
cons: Some boards are sketchy and poorly maintained. Pay doesn't match up with work load. Management bends rules to benefit them but punishes you when it doesn't matter to them.

title: Office Manager
pros: Some autonomy in the individual plants, must have Good GM for this to work.... Decent support from Corporate office. Decent pay, good benefit options. Great hours! Love working with most everyone in our plant! Company as a whole cares about the community and the customer experience.
cons: No place for advancement for certain positions. Don't feel as if Office Managers are very respected or valued in this company.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: Lamar Outdoor is a great place to work. The work/life balance is incredible. Collaboration between corporate and the individual plants couldn't be better. It's a fun and innovative industry and I'm proud to be a part of it. If you work hard and put in the effort, the sky is the limit. Great benefits as well.
cons: New hardware/software roll-outs could happen at less busy times of the year, but it's manageable.

title: Stay away. There are much better jobs out there.
pros: The only pro to the job is you spend most days in the field away from clueless management.
cons: When you give small people authority it goes to their head. Managers at the Collinsville, IL location are egotistical maniacs. Frequently throwing temper tantrums and do not conduct themselves in a professional manner. They bow down to any superiors but treats their employees like trash. They do not have the slightest idea of how a billboard is installed because they’ve never done it, yet somehow are in charge. Stay away from this company if you don’t want to be underpaid, disrespected, threatened, and lied to.

title: Sales Intern
pros: Nice people that were nice to work with Easy work and never really made me do too much Wanted to keep me on to work in sales
cons: General Manager was not interested in anything People who were there for a long time felt they owned the place

title: Fast pace environment and must be able to multi task.
pros: Getting out and meeting new people and then building relationships with them.
cons: structure is not set up very well for bottom tier sales reps.

title: Good benefits, but overworked with no acknowledgement.
pros: Good benefits. Stock can be purchased at a discounted rate. In the right departments there is a good community feeling.
cons: Expected to work lots of overtime with no pay, no comp time, and no acknowledgement for having done so. Travel at a moments notice to anywhere the company decides is "an emergency" and for unknown durations.

title: Wonderful Place Helpful People
pros: The work environment is second to none, coworkers/superiors are extremely helpful and easy to communicate with. Lamar is all about a "family" attitude and it shows-- everyone I worked with was a pleasure to be around, sure everyone has off days but 9 times out of 10 I really enjoyed my time in the office.
cons: coworkers may seem cliquish at first, but those walls are easy to break down if you are outgoing and personable.

title: Good company, weird culture in operations dept.
pros: Decent pay. They'll get you certifications. They have company parties at good restaurants. They supply the expensive things you need.
cons: Work at 3am. The foreman is a great worker but a horrible leader. You'll never get any advice from him, but he'll sure throw you under the bus if you make a mistake.

title: Great Office Environment - Good Pay
pros: Each Plant is it's own microcosm, so this is just one location. Great flexibility, large, quiet workspace. Coffee and other beverages provided. Lunch provided periodically.
cons: istent hours and workload. Little to no expectation to work outside work hours.

title: Low pay for back breaking work.
pros: Lots of leeway. Good benefits. Steady hours. Paid holidays. Starts at ten vacations days and five sick days. Understanding management.
cons: Dangerous situations. The pay is entirely too low for the conditions that we are put in on a daily basis. The management doesn’t appreciate

title: Overall good place to work
pros: The pay is very fair for work required. It is a friendly company both on the corporate level and local level. Benefits are offered to employees very quickly upon hire. They are always looking for ways to improve practices.
cons: Health benefits are expensive and don't cover as much as I think they should. Corporate launches new initiatives without one part of the company talking to another.

title: MIS Department Is A Joke
pros: The corporate headquarters is a nice building. It is a great place to work if you want to fly under the radar. As long as you come in on time, you can spend most of your day coasting. Your only other responsibility is to attend the occasional meeting to talk about the project you're supposed to be working on. This usually involves blaming others in your department, or some made-up technical issue, for things not getting done.
cons: The MIS department is a cesspool of incompetence. Avoid at all costs if you are eager to learn or be involved with good technology. Any attempt to help them evolve past the 20th century will be shunned and you will be labeled a "troublemaker." At this point, instead of firing you, they will methodically bully (i.e. targeted monitoring, verbal abuse, pay disparity, etc.) you until you quit. For most people, this can go, and has gone, on for years. Even if you manage to stay in good graces, vertical movement is virtually unheard of. Promotions for developers manly come in the form of title change, but rarely ever incorporate any advance in autonomy or pay. As a whole, the office political culture is out of control. Every department head openly hates each of his counterparts, actively pitting departments against one another, just to try and score petty political points. They are all fake-smiles and handshakes in public, however. None of them will actually stand up and call the other one out because they are all complicit in playing the childish game.

title: Terrible General Management
pros: It was a job with a steady pay check, they offered health benefits a vacation time
cons: They do not value local customers or local sales reps at all. There is always another customer out there and there are always other sales reps who will come along that they can pay less. The General Manager changed the sales reps compensation plan 6 times in one year, moving the goal post so the reps would never make their quota and he didn't have to pay them commissions. It's a revolving door of local sales reps because they are not valued.

title: Sr. Account Executive
pros: flexable hours, good product, some good employees to work with.
cons: low commission percentage little to no appreciation shown always wanting more, never good enough.

title: Account Executive
pros: Great benefits and research information provided from corporate to help sell. Training was amazing.
cons: Each office is run independently, there is no accountability for GM'S and they are protected. There is a reason you have high turnover in some of these offices.

title: Great HQ Support, Poor Management
pros: 1. Great support from the HQ of Lamar 2. Decent benefits 3. Great learning job for marketing industry
cons: 1. Culture varies depending on office location 2. Some managers are stuck in their ways, not open to constructive criticism 3. The office I was located at had "clicks" which made it uneasy to speak openly

title: Caveat emptor. Quality of management is hit or miss.
pros: Opportunities to stretch job description and gain experience. Solid benefits; Up to 2.5% Employer Match on 401k. Employee Stock Purchase Program allows 10% of earnings max contribution, with additional 15% discount on market stock price (LAMR).
cons: Lower marks for diversity, equity and inclusion at Corporate Offices. Work balance can heavily favor management. Expect low to fair market offers with few perks to compensate.

title: Very laid back and friendly work culture.
pros: The dress code is very casual and the work environment is very friendly and relaxed. The corporate office is very modern and unique. I've received comments that it resembles something out of a Google office. There's a full kitchen that would allow you to cook just about anything.
cons: Compensation is typically on the lower side.

title: Flexible, but Okay Company
pros: The training was awesome, there is flexibility with work, and always improving sales materials.
cons: Not many incentives to work hard, the systems in place don't accommodate large markets and corporate can't fathom that. Each office is ran independently, but it's hard to work with other markets if they run a different flow within the same company.

title: Very Unethical and Very Unprofessional Company
pros: Job was actually good and fun. They help lots of parties at the main office in Baton Rouge and always had a keg of beer at the party. The Christmas Party was incredible.
cons: I worked for Lamar Advertising as a contract employee for only one year. During that time, I have never seen a more unprofessional organization. The job was really good. I enjoyed going to work daily. But, on the other side of the spectrum, Lamar employees were dictating my destiny without consulting me first on it. One employee had an issue with me. He actually worked right across from me. But, he never spoke to me one on one about the issues he had with me. Instead, he went straight to his supervisor and probably the guy that was over the department overall. He complained to them about me. In return, they spoke to me. Problem is, they never gave me any information that explained what I did or whom made the complaint because they did not want there to be issues between me and the person. So, I was told someone complained about me. But, I was never given anything to defend myself or make the situation right. Apparently, this same Lamar employee went and complained again about me, only this time, he told the boss that I "hit” him while at work that day. The boss let me work the remainder of that day and never said one word about the complaint. I got home that night and I had a call from the staffing agency I worked for. She told me about the complaint made against me and said my boss would not need to come back to Lamar Advertising ever again to work. This allegation made against me about “hitting” this employee while at work was completely bogus. How can I prove this? I was never charged with a crime by the police for assault and battery. The staffing agency never pursued charges against me. Lamar Advertising never pursued charges against me. The person that made the allegation never pursued charges against me. If I had physically hit another employee while on the job, I believe I would have gotten in much more trouble that being fired from Lamar Advertising. To make matters worse, the staffing agency fired me 4 days after this all took place. I was then unemployed for a full month before getting another job. So, if you decide to work as contract labor for Lamar Advertising, they will dispose of you like you are a piece of garbage and not lose a bit of sleep over it. Very unethical and very unprofessional!

title: Great Place
pros: The money is very good once you have an established territory. Great Company at the corporate level
cons: poor training at the local level. Corporate is very savvy but they don't send corporate executives out to the local plants to train. The GMs are usually old men with the desire to grow and learn new things. The plant runs like its 1996

title: Flexible and Welcoming Work Environment
pros: Flexible Work Environment. Great Corporate Culture. Awesome staff and managers. Beneficial training. Offer an array of benefits, perks, and time off. Management listens and is attentive to staff requests, concerns, and/or needs.
cons: The corporation and staff tend to stay set in their ways. Change can tend to be slow and adaptability can be difficult, especially with technology and system processes.

title: Great Company, Great Benefits
pros: Great company culture and benefits. As a fresh graduate, I found Lamar to be very welcoming and provided a whole lot of experience in sales, marketing, and operations.
cons: Sometimes the Sales staff can get too comfortable with the support, depending on the plant you're working at. Remind yourself to never take on too much of their work (like prospecting/contacting leads before they do.)

title: 5 stars overall. Areas in need of improvement, just like any organization.
pros: A company based on Autonomy, fun work environment, ethical core values, and a great work-life balance. A Financially sound organization.
cons: They could use more individual support and future planning. They tend to be a bit disconnected from corporate to individual office life and contributions.

title: Not a place to grow
pros: You can do your own thing as long as you get enough number (output of graphics). Portfolio builder Name recognition for future employment
cons: -Your work is not appreciated -No room to grow -They value quantity over quality (even if they say otherwise) -Favoritism and racism -Unfriendly work environment (Cliquey) -high turnover -Low pay

title: Broken Promises
pros: Laid Back Environment and some good co-workers
cons: Keep you hanging on with promises of more pay or bonuses. End of the world for small mistakes but no praise for great job, always have to do better. Not paid for your performance or worth.

title: Hard to deal with at first but hard work may pay off...... Eventually
pros: Guaranteed 40, insurance, sick and vacation days the moment you start
cons: Hard on body, immediate boss can't give raise only cheap gm

title: Great Company
pros: Great work-life balance, solid benefits, ability to grow your own business and income level, fantastic team-first environmnet.
cons: There are not many layers to management, promotions within the company are too few and far between, sometimes sales goals are unrealistic

title: Terrible company to work for - pay is low - management is awful.
pros: Enjoyed working with the majority of co-workers (not including management). Office location made for a great commute.
cons: Terrible, unethical working environment driven by management. Religion and politics were heavily discussed in work meetings. The pay was no where it should've been for work/tasks completed. Micromanaging style. Not a female friendly company. Left the company in 2012 along with a number of other employees, all of whom cited management as their reason for leaving.

title: No Appreation for Good Work
pros: Supposed to be a set schedule, vacation time, sick time, ok pay
cons: Terrible management, you work will never be good enough, no opportunity for growth, leaders are dictators but are not willing to get their hands dirty, manage from an office chair instead of coming on the field and actually seeing what needs to be done

title: If you value respect and good leadership, this isn’t the place for you.
pros: Ummm...sometimes they would bring beer?
cons: Poor work life balance, toxic leadership, poor management, no care or respect for employees, apparently they are strong proponents of leading through intimidation tactics; which does not a good leader make. Poor communication to employees. Employee safety is also low on the totem pole of concerns. 10/10 do NOT recommend.

title: Good not great
pros: Freedom with decent benefits. My current plant cares about their employees.
cons: truction foreman

title: Great Company
pros: Been with Lamar for several years. It's a great company. Nationwide but still feels like a close family. Best place I've ever worked
cons: I don't really have anything negative to say. There are a few quirks, but nothing different than what you see in every other office.

pros: Great bosses, no micro management. Team members become like office family. Some oportunities come up to learn new technology. Company has a solid history with good family values. Salary is good, work is steady. Schedule is flexible. There are many perks to working at Lamar.
cons: Nothing bad to say here.

title: A Good Place to Start, but Run Badly
pros: LG has the largest graphics department in the southeast, so it's a great place to meet and learn from talented people.
cons: Run by micromanagers who are eager to place blame instead of taking responsibility. As a result, morale is low and the creative is not nearly as good as it could be.

title: Fast paced and lots of growth
pros: Established company with full offering of benefits. Good people.
cons: Cross department collaboration isn’t the greatest. Acquisitions of other organizations create salary compression and poor morale with existing employees. Heavy workloads in some deportments with average pay. Corporate systems are dated and not user friendly and there are many.

pros: Casual environment, great parties, gave me my start. The benefits are pretty good, affordable. Very flat organization so there isn't a lot of bureaucracy involved.
cons: Very low pay compared to other companies in this industry. Upper management is protected. If you make a complaint, it will be investigated and nothing will happen.

title: Good learning experience but is a lot of repetition
pros: Great people to work with. You’ll be awesome at photoshop after working in it every day. Holiday PTO and sick leave are great. Good benefits
cons: Not as much creative freedom as I’d like and it’s hard to stare at a computer 8 hours a day doing the same things.

title: Fantastic place to work
pros: I love the empowerment and support when you need it that my managers give to me. Fun and amazing place to work.
cons: Office is old and everyone in same room in very close proximity to one another. No other cons that I can think of.

title: Acoount Executive
pros: Your pretty much free to do what you want in your day as long as making buget
cons: Pay is terrible . ( This is NY and needs a different pay structure)

title: Sales Rep
pros: Good corporate training, interesting products, small local office. Coworkers were great.
cons: Passive aggressive manager, one of my markets was 3 hours away, cut car allowance, even though covid showed management it's possible to work from home they want salespeople in the office. How commissions were earned changed frequently.

title: Corporate Account Executive
pros: Fun atmosphere. Great people. Caring and social culture.
cons: No real advancement to increase income beyond a certain level and not enough PTO

cons: I wasn’t employed long enough to have an accurate opinion.

title: Short staffed

title: Good Company

cons: If you are salaried, overtime isn't compensated. Only an issue a couple of weeks per year for this job.

title: Great people
pros: Great people to work with, decent pay but with many acquisitions happening locally, they didn’t hire additional support in any department and it was very very stressful atmosphere.
cons: Pay raise would have been nice and new office manager is awful

title: Leadership by Intimidation

Even after multiple complaints and an HR investigation, senior management remains in place.....hmmmmm. Have seen many highly qualified and successful reps leave for 1 reason only; management

title: Great Company!
pros: Even though it is a multi-billion dollar company, it feels like a small business at times. Each office around the country operates independently. People here care about each other.
cons: I'm the ONLY person working in my office's art department. There is no back-up locally.

title: Level 1 installer

cons: No promise you the world in mineral make excuses and why they're not going to give it to you

title: Management are bullies, they harass long time employees to make them leave. Horrible experience.

cons: Pay is below average. Manager micromanages to the point of tracking employees on his phone all day.

title: Prepress
pros: There were amazing co-workers, the ones that make the day a good one.

title: Just fine
pros: Decent pay and benefits. The company paid for a business trip to Baton Ridge, which was fun.

title: Family Dynamics
pros: Lamar has a family like dynamic that makes you feel comfortable in the office and with your co workers.
cons: You have to put a lot of time and energy into getting anything changed because it is such an old company with lots of precedents already in place.

title: Account Executive
pros: The company has family values.
cons: Not enough promotions for women as much as men. It seems.

title: Overall great experience
pros: The companies values are great. The work-life balance is awesome. Very little micromanaging.
cons: Each office runs as a separate entity, so one market might be great to work in, but another may not. It is hit or miss in different regions.

title: Needs to value all employees
pros: Great people to work for. Not micro managed. As long as you did your work, no questions asked.
cons: Pay and hours could be better. Not much offered to office as sales team when you're all to be a team.

title: Lamar
pros: I wish I could say there are pros to working here. I guess it depends on your title and how you make upper management feel about themselves. I would stay away!
cons: Upper Management bends the rules to meet the current needs (daily needs or personal needs) They are not nice people and play head games to suit their needs. Full of lies and other shady things. too much to list. But not a good place to work!

title: Not a bad place to work
pros: Good benefits ants decent so saleries motivate you to stay with company. Management is filled with really great people.
cons: Culture of making unnessary promises

title: Great company. Top management has lost touch with plant level realities
pros: Good benefits reasonable pay good training
cons: Upper management out of touch with ordinary employees. Bottom line profit is all that matters

title: Sales
pros: You make your success! You can make a lot of money and have freedom to work independently most of the time. The flexibility is good for working parents.

title: Account Executive
pros: Ability to help client, creativity

title: Good and Bad 'Graphic Design' Job
pros: Working at Lamar offered: 1. National recognition - it looked good on a resume. 2. Career Advancement - growth as a worker and valuable on-the-job experience. Also, designing billboards provided a unique talent which not many designers possess. 3. Networking Benefits - the company is huge and you can make a lot of contacts. 4. Independence - After training, managers rarely designed over your shoulder and allowed workers to freely use their own ideas and talents when creating billboard designs.
cons: Working at Lamar lacked: 1. Leadership - manager did not have 4-year degree or managerial training in the Graphic Design field. In particular, my direct manager was a bit immature. 2. Worker Morale - many workers were negative, dissatisfied with management, or egotistical. 3. Worker Motivation - benefits and advanced positions were unfairly appropriated. Among lower workers, there seemed to be a distrust for management. Rewards for a job well done were often not much more than an "atta-boy" e-mail shot around to everyone in the office. 4. Teamwork - Competition among designers often inhibited designers' ability to rely on one another for thoughtful critique of their work. 5. The Work Itself - This is *not* work in a graphic design studio, it is an *advertisement design* job in which designers make billboards per the Sales Rep's direct instructions. Other projects were hard to come by (i.e.: logo design, poster or flyer design, etc.) and often given to managers.

title: Great place if you like low pay.
pros: Co-workers, whether in your location, other plants, or HQ tend to be friendly, helpful, and willing to teach you the ins-and-outs of the business and your job. Hours tend to be short, a strict 40 hour week. Everyone bolts for the door at 5pm and the boss (GM) locks the door at 5:15. No need to take work home with you, leave your cell phone on, etc. Your responsibility ends when you leave the office. The majority of the VP/GM's are pretty reasonable to work for. There is some flexibility if you need to alter your schedule for personal business, all they care is that you get your 40 hours in. There are dozens of plants to work at across the country, and you have the opportunity to apply for other locations if you choose. Most of the offices are pretty small and there is very little of the corporate politics you usually find at large companies.

If you're an account exec, real estate mgr, etc. covering a lot of turf, it comes nowhere near the cost of operating your car unless you drive an old clunker. There is little to no opportunity for advancement, unless you're a account exec who plans on staying for 20 years, at which time you may be considered for a VP/GM positiion. If you're not working in HQ, senior management is non-visible and out of the picture - might be a good thing though.
